turns.speaker: WHORE
turns.text: Papers.  Last Medcheck two weeks ago. A-1.  Disease free.  Guaranteed by the State.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I don't care if you've got the Good Housekeeping seal of approval... I'm not looking for company.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: Belle Dee. I'm from over the mountain.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: From over the mountain --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I'll take it.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: No -- that's for me to do.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Let's dance together -- Belle.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: No, Jabez -- your place is with your wife --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Golly, Belle, that was a good idea -- we should do that every morning.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: We will --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: We'll cook 'em ourselves. You'll help me, Belle.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: Of course I will.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: The people, Jabez -- the people.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: The -- folks or people, what's the difference among friends?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Hey, you! Watch out there -- you're scuffing my Brussels carpet -- Consarn them.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: Jabez! Careful --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Oh --  Didn't mean to talk like that in front of a lady.  Get some wine for the Squire, Belle.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What are those people doing there? What do they want?

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: They're just outsiders. They want to see how fine Jabez Stone lives these days. They're waiting for your guests, too --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Who are these people?

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: They are all friends of mine -- from over the mountain.  Welcome! Help yourselves to drinks! Glad you could come! Have a good time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- ?

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: I've brought you something to keep you warm, Mrs. Stone --

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: You're not resting well, are you? I know -- it's that music.  You need your sleep. Is there anything else you want?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, thank you -- what's your name?

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: Belle --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thank you, Belle --

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: That's my business. -- Now, it's all right, Daniel.  What did he do?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He lied to me again.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: I see why you're here -- you knew that nobody was coming.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: You're lying.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Lying to you -- Why should I?

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: You know that you're in my house.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I know -- and you could show me the door. You would, too, if you weren't still hoping the guests might arrive.

turns.speaker: BELLE
turns.text: You think you're so smart, Mrs. Stone. You wanted to be near Jabez. It looked like your big chance tonight, but you're wrong, you can't win him back -- not that way.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's my problem, Belle.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Hello, Colonel! Want a lift?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Well, I wouldn't mind.  But my name's Daniel Stone.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: All right, Daniel. Jump in.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Gee -- that Fair --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: It hasn't opened yet?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: No -- but I can hardly wait -- Mister -- tell me, will there really be --  -- a man that eats fire?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Guess there will, if it says so.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: And two unpara-- unparalleled Cir-cass-ian beauties? What is that?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Young man -- you got me there.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: 'N Daniel Webster will be there.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: A varied list of attractions. And which would you like to see first, Dan'l?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: I think I'd like to begin with the fire-eater --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: And what about Daniel Webster?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Well, I thought he'd come in the middle.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: And serve him right!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Daniel! Don't ever let me catch you doing that again!

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Why? It don't hurt.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: It does hurt! And don't you do it again.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Make them go faster, Mr.... ?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: No, Daniel -- they are not race horses. They are good old friends of mine. I call 'em Constitution and Bill of Rights, the most dependable pair for long journeys. I've got one called Missouri Compromise, too, and then there's a Supreme Court -- fine, dignified horse, though you do have to push him now and then.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Golly -- I'd like to see all your horses!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Maybe you can, sometime, Daniel. I'm a farmer, you know, and like to show my farm -- but the thing I'd like to show you most, you'll have to see for yourself.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: What's that, sir?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well -- it's high and it's wide and it goes a long way and there is a wind blowing through it and a blue roof over it -- it's the hills up here and the rivers running south and the new States growing in the West.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Anybody can see that.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You're wrong, Mr. Stone. There are people who live and die without e'er seeing it. They can't see the country for the money in their pockets -- And some think their state's the country, or the way they live is the country, and they're willing to split the country because of that. Well, I hope you'll meet all those, when you're grown. You'll meet the fire-eaters and the Circassian beauties -- that's part of the fair, to be sure. But if we'd had to depend on them, in a permanent way, the country would have stopped at the Allegheny mountains.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: But it didn't stop. I know it didn't stop. Granny told me it didn't.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: No, siree, it didn't. And it won't -- no matter what happens -- just as long as the folks at the fair believe in freedom and Union. So --  Giddyap, Constitution -- and let's keep going, Mr. Stone.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, you did, Daniel! I saw it from the window. And then to lie about it! Give me that beanshooter, Daniel!

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: It's mine, Ma! Pa made it for me -- and I'm not going to give it to anyone!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Daniel give me that beanshooter!

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: No! No! I won't.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Daniel! ...  I've stood just about as much as I can bear!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Daniel, you ought to be in bed.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: No, no, I don't want to go to bed. I want to be here for the party.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Mama!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Daniel! ... You must go to sleep.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: I don't want to be up there all alone, Mama.... I want to be with you.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All right, darling.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Granny, when do we move to the new house?

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Move? -- We are not going to move -- the old one is good enough for us.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: But I like the new one better.

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: That's just too bad --

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: Lan's to goodness, what happened to that hen? Did you use that beanshooter again?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: I did not, Grandma.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Grandma, look at me!

turns.speaker: MA STONE
turns.text: I see you! Riding pretty high, ain't you? Look out you don't fall off.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Not me!

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Howdy, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Howdy, Hank.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Kin you spare a moment for me Jabez?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Why, of course, Hank -- I've always got time for a neighbor. What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Well -- here's how it is ...Tom Sharp, Eli Higgins and a couple of others been talking to me about -- that new sort of organization -- grange they call it. What you think about it?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I don't know -- don't seem much of an idea to me.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Yes, but what does a farmer do if he don't want to get roped in some more by them loan sharks?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Oh -- you don't have to go to Miser Stevens while I'm around.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Don't I? ... Say, that's mighty white of you, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Not at all, Hank ... not at all. Glad to help you.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Thanks, Jabez -- I really wouldn't need very much ... if you could let me have some seed to start off with enough for spring planting ...

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Say ... about the interest ...

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Now don't you worry about that. You just leave it all to me. We won't talk business now ... just bear this in mind ... I'm not the man to get rich on other people's hard luck.... No, sir... not me! ...

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Loan shark -- hey?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Too bad it didn't happen to Miser Stevens.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Are you one of old Stevens' customers too?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Sure am.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Yes, it's the debt and the lien and the mortgage that eats up the farmer!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Sure does. But I'll have to sleep on it a couple of nights.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: That's fair enough, Jabez. Man's got a right to mull things over. We'll drive round again, week or so.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I am just thinkin' -- now they mightn't like the idea down in Washington.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Why not! There's a bill up in Congress to give us a uniform law of bankruptcy. Daniel Webster is fighting for it right now--

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Black Dan'l?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Howdy, Mr. Stone. We've come round to ask you if you made up your mind to join the Grange?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What Grange?

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: That farmers' association -- we were talking about the other day.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Well -- we don't mean to force you, Jabez Stone -- but -- it's only for your own good.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I'll look out for myself! ... Now go away -- leave me alone.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: Jabez -- will you join our Grange now?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Why, thank you, Tom. I was going to ask you if you thought I could.

turns.speaker: TOM SHARP
turns.text: We'll be mighty glad to have you with us.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You're not -- Dorothy.

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: No. She's gone.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: She couldn't be gone!

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: But she is -- I've taken her place. Don't you remember -- you wrote me a letter. Mrs. Stone was too ill.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Never mind. What's your name?

turns.speaker: THE WOMAN
turns.text: Belle.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Belle --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Stevens!

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Well, Stone -- have you got the money?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I barely managed to scrape up a bit for you. I thought if I made a kind of part payment --

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: No, Stone!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: -- in gold.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: I'd like to know where you'd get it....

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You know -- some folks are just lucky. Others pick gold right out of the air.  Like that!

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Real! Sheriff, you are a witness that this money is paid me voluntarily, and while it does not satisfy the mortgage, it has become my property.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Doesn't satisfy, eh? Well -- that's too bad....

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Mornin', Jabez ...

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Hello, Stevens ... you're early today.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Yes, I wanted to get here before the others.... I want to talk to you alone.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Some other time, Stevens.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Good evening -- I'm sorry, Jabez -- I'm a little late.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: No, you're not.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Where's everybody?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I dunno -- I can't figure it out. I've invited them all. Why don't they come?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Now run along, Daniel.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: What a fine boy you have, Jabez. How old is he now?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Almost seven.  No -- no, he's not seven yet I am sure --

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Well -- it seems to me -- I remember when you paid me--

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: You are afraid!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Afraid ... of what?

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: -- of what happens after we die!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Are you plumb crazy, man! What do you think happens? We're buried -- that's all.

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: But what becomes of our souls?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Why do you fret about something that isn't there?

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: Don't say that -- I know it is --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: All right -- so it's buried with you!

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: What if one hasn't a soul any more? What of that?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Huh? -- What's that?  Well -- what about it? Who cares, anyhow?

turns.speaker: STEVENS
turns.text: I do -- and I think you should too.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Stevens -- what's all this leading up to? You know something. Come on! Out with it -- you know something about me!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Do you deny that you called me? I've known people in other States who went back on their word. But I didn't expect it in New Hampshire.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You can't say that to me! I'm New Hampshire. If I say I called you, I did.  I guess I did.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: You've had a lot of bad luck these days. And yet -- it's all so unnecessary. When I think of your opportunities --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Opportunities?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Of course. Why man, you have one of the richest farms in the county.  You just go about it the wrong way -- so many men do. Hard work -- well, that's all right for people who don't know how to do anything else. It's all right for people who aren't lucky -- but once you're lucky -- you don't work for other people. You make them work for you.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well, now, Mister, that sounds all right. But--

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: A clever man like yourself -- he can find money anywhere. Money to pay his bills -- money for his wife and his children -- money to be a rich man. All he needs is a friend to point it out to him.  Like that!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Where did it come from?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh, you know the old story -- the Hessian wagon train that was ambushed on the way to Saratoga. Some of the gold has been buried under your barn!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes, why shouldn't it?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Yes, of course, people forgot -- or the men who knew about it died, you know how these things happen.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It's mine?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: That's right, Mr. Stone -- there is --  -- just one little formality. I'd like your signature here -- see. And when it's done -- it's done for seven years.  It's our usual form. Of course -- we may be able to take up the question of a renewal in due time.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What does it mean here -- about my soul?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Well, why should that worry you. A soul -- a soul is nothing. Can you see it, smell it, touch it? -- No! -- Think of it -- this soul -- your soul -- a nothing, against seven whole years of good luck! You will have money and all that money can buy. Upon my word, Neighbor Stone, if it weren't for my firm's reputation for generous dealing--

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: No, no! Give it to me!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: A pin, Neighbor Stone! I'm afraid, you'll have to prick your finger -- but what's a little pain to a lucky man?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Excellent. A firm, fair signature. One that will last till doomsday.  My dear Neighbor Stone, I congratulate you! You're going to be the richest man in New Hampshire!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well, I'll be --

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Yes, indeed. But not now. Not for seven years. Oh, I almost forgot -- what is the date?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: The seventh day of April --

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: 1840. Well, that'll take us to the seventh day of April in 1847.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Good evening, Neighbor Stone.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Look here now--

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh come, Neighbor Stone. I wouldn't cut that tree if I were you. It means a breach of contract.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I don't care.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: But you should, now that you are becoming a father.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Leave your tongue off of that!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh, certainly. I shan't even come to the christening -- it would be tactless and in wretched bad taste.  But I may send a friend of mine -- just for old sake's sake. Yes, I might do that.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Why, Mr. Stone, you look so worried. Can I be of any service?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You promised me prosperity, happiness, love, money, friendship --

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Just a minute, neighbor Stone. I promised you money and all that money can buy. I don't recall any other obligations. But let's look at the contract.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: .... Miser Stevens' soul, Mr. Stone. Yes -- I am sorry for the disturbance.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: He ain't dead -- he's dancing in there.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: He was --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Are they all as -- small -- as that?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Small? Oh, I see what you mean. Why, they vary.  Now a man like Daniel Webster, if I ever get hold of him, I'd have to build a special box for him and even at that, I imagine, the wing spread would be astonishing.  In your case --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: My time isn't up yet.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Trying to break our contract again, Mr. Stone?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I'm through with you.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: What a headstrong fellow! Well -- I guess you're quite prepared to suffer the consequences.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I have still a year -- a year to make up for everything.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Oh no, you violated clause five of our contract and I could collect right now, if I chose.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Not now! Not now!  -- Let me make up -- let me make up.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Suddenly you seem quite desperate, Mr. Stone --  -- You know I'm a good-natured man. I'm always open to reason. With a little security -- I might--

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Anything -- anything. -- You can have it all back -- that money -- the new house -- my farm -- the whole caboodle!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: I'm afraid that's hardly the sort of security I was thinking of --  You see -- there is that promising little fellow, your son ...

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: No! No! No! Not him -- not my son -- I'd rather go with you -- right now.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Come, come, Mr. Stone, you are a little upset. It's not fair to bargain with you now. -- I'll give you until midnight, Mr. Stone, but not one minute more. Ah, then you'll come with me indeed.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Well now, Mr. Stone, did you make up your mind?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Are you willing to give me your son in exchange for an extension of our contract?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Never!

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Jabez Stone -- did you or did you not sign this document?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes, I did -- but you tricked me into signing it! You told me my soul was nothing ... that I could forget all about a soul, in exchange for money. That was a lie, a lie, a lie.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: That is highly irrelevant to this case, Your Honor.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- yes, I am the richest man -- too rich. I can't think of anything but money. That's the trouble with me.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: But, Mr. Stone, I am hardly to blame for the pricking of your wholly unnecessary conscience.  Is this your signature?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You know darn well it is.

turns.speaker: SCRATCH
turns.text: Gentlemen, the prosecution rests.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ten throws -- Mr. Webster?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Ten throws it is.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You win. Will you ride to the village with me, Mr. Stone?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Webster.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I don't seem to be so very popular after all -- in Cross Corners.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Seems like it's my fault, Mr. Webster.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Not at all, lad -- not at all.  For a good game of horseshoes I would always sacrifice fame and acclaim.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Here's a man who knows what's good for Dan'l Webster! Medford rum! Ah, a breath of the Promised Land!  To the champion of the Iron Horseshoe, Jabez Stone!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Thanks, Mr. Webster!  To the champion of the whole United States -- Dan'l Webster!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Eloquent speech, Neighbor Stone -- couldn't have done better myself --  -- under the circumstances.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mr. Webster -- I'd like you to meet my wife, Mary.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Well -- I'll be -- if it isn't little Mary Sampson from Franklin.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well -- Mr. Webster! This is a great day for me. Come on in, sir. I want you to take the seat of honor and meet all my guests!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: That's just fine, Neighbor Stone -- but -- I have to be pretty careful of my seats of honor -- where I sit, I mean. You see, the whole country sort of has its eye on me, Jabez -- anybody in public life has that difficulty -- even you, Jabez. They watch us carefully, our neighbors and our enemies, and they see much more than we think they do -- and understand much more. My friends all like to think that I've got the good of mankind always at heart, and I've got to make sure that those I deal with have the good of mankind always at heart, too. Do you know what I'm talking about, Jabez?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What -- what's on your mind?

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You, Jabez Stone -- you and a lot of poor farmers, hereabouts -- good men of the earth who are in trouble because of you. Or -- am I wrong about those contracts, Mr. Stone?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Contracts? -- Yes, they have contracts with me -- lots of 'em -- but -- but that's all right. Without me and my money, they wouldn't have anything.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: They'd have a good neighbor, Jabez -- and that's worth much more than anything else -- much, much more!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I'm sorry you can't see that, I know you could once -- you made a little speech once, that I'll always remember and I know the others do too --  They remember and they see how you have changed. That's why they didn't want to come tonight to you, Jabez -- you're as blind as a Burma bat, with your gold pot! Mind you, it's not the money, I've been talking about, it's what you make of it.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I -- I don't know what you're talking about! I -- I haven't time to listen to all this --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: No -- you haven't time -- You haven't time for your mother, or your wife, or your child.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It's your fault! You brought Daniel Webster here -- just to try to make a fool of me! You played the sneak behind my back -- made up all sorts of lies against me! You can get yourself out of my home -- go back to the other house -- that old place, where you belong -- I don't want to -- to talk to you again!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: It's here you said that you closed the deal with him?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Webster -- it was here where it all began.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I see. And this is where he'd like to collect, too.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- at midnight.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: They make plucky women in New England.  H'm ... how long have we to wait?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Not long -- now.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Then I'll just christen the jug, with your permission, Stone. Somehow or other, waiting's wonderfully shorter with a jug.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: There's nothing like it. I saw an inchworm take a drop of it once, and he stood right up on his hind legs and bit a bee. Come -- try a nip!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: There's no joy in it for me.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Oh, come, man, come. Just because you've sold your soul to the devil that needn't make you a teetotaler.

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: You were worried, Jabez, weren't you?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well, I --

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: I know -- that was mighty queer Medford -- knew it the minute I tasted it. But it takes more than that to down Daniel Webster.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Ma says breakfast's ready, Mr. Webster!

turns.speaker: WEBSTER
turns.text: Breakfast ... Ah! ... Come along friends, Ma Stone's a cook this side of heaven.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Coming along, Jabez?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Shall we?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Why -- good morning, Squire.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Morning, Jabez.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Ahem -- we want to have a little confidential talk with you, Neighbor Stone. Don't like to take a man away from his planting -- but sometimes --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Come right into the parlor, won't you, folks.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mighty good of you to come out, Squire -- sparing all this time to --  Sheriff, too -- and Schoolmaster -- mighty nice.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Ahem -- Neighbor Stone, we want--

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Headache -- Squire?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Worst I had in years -- ahem -- starting a spring cold, I guess -- er -- don't happen to have a bit of camomile tea in the house, do you, Stone?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Camomile tea!

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: And so, Jabez Stone, in the name of the Whig Party of Cross Corners, we offer you the nomination of that party for Selectman.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Selectman? Selectman of the village? Me?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: But -- I was just lucky.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Well? Don't a politician have to be?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Howdy, Squire! Howdy! Oh -- how do you do, Squire.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: How do you do, Belle? How are you, Jabez?  Well -- mighty elegant house you got here.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You really think so?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Well, Jabez -- I'm a little pressed for time. You wanted to discuss something -- some business --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Oh yes -- yes. Won't take a minute. Can you keep a secret?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Why of course --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Dan'l Webster is coming to my party.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Dan'l Webster?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- and that's the reason I wanted to talk with you. You got my invitation?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Now look -- here's a list of the people I invited -- they're all the right kind of people -- or did I miss anybody?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: The only one you missed -- is the President.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You think that's a joke? I had him on there too, but I was afraid Dan'l Webster might feel insulted.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You keep that -- that's for you. I want you to talk up the party to make sure that the best folks really come.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: You want me to go around --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes  siree -- that's the idea. Get them all here and then say: "Look, folks -- here's Daniel Webster, my guest of honor." Golly, I can see their eyes pop already.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: You mean that's all you had me come out here for?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Now, Squire, you're not going to let me down. We still want to do a lot of business together, don't we?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Well -- yes --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: That's fine. Now you can tell people all about the house, but don't mention Webster.

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: You are not so sure that he'll come.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Oh yes -- I am -- want to bet?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: Why not -- ?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: SQUIRE
turns.text: 5000 -- that's just what I owe you.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Shake!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- help!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Coming.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Down, Shep! Down!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He only wants you to throw the stick for him, Jabez. I guess he's feeling the spring a-coming, too.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: All right -- only he needn't dirty my pants!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: What is that smile on your face?  Is there anything wrong with me?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Now, Jabez! I've got on my Sunday bonnet and I'm going to church with my husband. Almost the first time since the beginning of winter -- and if that isn't an occasion, I don't know what is.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You're right, Mary.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I think his leg is broken.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I remember Dad used to say sometimes, when they were handing out hard luck, the farmers got there first.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez, don't you remember your own wedding? We said it's for better or worse. We said it's for richer or poorer.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: That's what we said.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's stubborn as a Stone.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Hold the splint tighter -- it's almost done.  Go on reading, Ma. This man, Job, he had troubles, didn't he?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well, I'll be -- there's a rig, turning in, by the gate.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: It's Tom Sharp and two other fellers -- Oh, glory -- where's my pants?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: " ... and if the final vote shall leave thousands of our fellow citizens and their families in hopeless distress, can we -- members of the Government -- go to our beds with a clear conscience, can we, without self- reproach, supplicate the Almighty Mercy to forgive us our debts as we forgive our debtors?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That's wonderful language. It would move a stone.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: If it would only move old Miser Stevens -- We've still got to pay him.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well -- what are we going to do?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We can still use my butter money.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Your butter money?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Do you think I'm grudging it?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- it's gone.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Not all of it?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- I had to pay the vet in full. He just wouldn't have treated the horse this time. After all, we can't very well do without a horse.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's all right, Jabez. We'll find something to pay Stevens.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: If the pig hadn't broke his leg, we could have taken him.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez! Couldn't you take a sack of seed instead?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: To save us work on the spring plowing?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You always said, the field uphill needs a rest, but if you think --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary, I'm a farmer -- always will be. To me seed isn't a thing to pay debts with, it's alive, more alive than anything -- but I guess you're right. We just got to do it. Oh -- how's it all going to end?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- you ought to talk to Tom about joining the Grange.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I will, Mary -- always thought a man could be stronger alone -- seems I've been wrong about that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Seed alone won't do, Mary. We have to throw the calf in.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh Jabez! And we were counting on ...  It's a lovely calf.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You're right, Mary it's a fine calf. That's why Stevens'll take it for the rest of the payment.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary--

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez ...

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- how do you feel?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I'll get the doctor.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, Jabez -- all I need is some rest -- You go and pay our debt. Everything'll be all right then ... everything.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- what would you do with a pot o' gold?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- what would you do?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Well -- I -- I don't know -- I would pay our debts and well -- maybe get a new bonnet, but -- really -- I think I would live the same.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- look! Hessian gold. I found it in the barn.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It feels fine now, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Will you come into town with me tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'd love to.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What do you think of that, Jabez?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Looks right elegant, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We must go on home, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes, Mary.  It's been a long day.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Remember, Mary, how he said it: "Couldn't have done better myself, Jabez Stone," and it was my first speech. I don't know what came into me, Mary. I just stood up and the words came flowing like water out of my mouth.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh, Jabez -- it was a wonderful day --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But I'm glad to be home again --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Tired?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Worried!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: There is nothing to worry about now.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You'll never change -- will you?

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- you just wait and see -- It's all -- just the beginning -- just the beginning -- of everything. I'll be the biggest man in New Hampshire and you'll be the wife of the biggest man.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's hope and promise in it, Jabez -- Planting and promise of good harvest to come.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Yes -- you are right, Mary. I can almost hear the little blades of grass a-starting up -- All the seeds a-stirring underneath the ground --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't take cold, Jabez.  Come -- it's warm in here.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary, get three cups of camomile tea for the Squire and the rest. They all feel colds coming on.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll get it, Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Thanks, Mary.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary! I'm -- Selectman of Cross Corners!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Oh -- Jabez.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: You could have knocked me down with a feather -- Selectman -- me.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'll never get my washing done.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: That's one thing I want to talk to you about, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Selectman!

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I'm serious.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It's very becoming to you, Mr. Selectman.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: But it's not very becoming to you to have your hands in the suds -- when the Squire and his wife --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But Jabez -- the washing has to be done --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Well -- that's the last time -- we'll have servants to do it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, no. I don't want to be idle.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: And I don't want to have a washwoman for a wife.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Jabez -- once you said we'd never change --

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: I wasn't used to being big -- wasn't used to thinking in big ways. Now, I've made up my mind.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ruined -- all the fields -- ruined.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary -- but look -- it didn't touch an ear of my corn -- we'll have a rich harvest.

turns.speaker: JABEZ
turns.text: Mary --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Hello, Jabez --  Here's your son.
